lg.l: What fruit comes of learning, pray?
if they do not serve the good feet
of the One of pure wisdom

div.p: (i - ḷ). ellā nūlkaḷaiyuṅ kaṟṟavark kakkalviyaṟivāṉāya payaṉ yātu, meyyuṇarviṉai yuṭaiyāṉatu nalla tāḷkaḷait toḻārāyiṉ, (e-ṟu).

The meaning ... : For those who have studied all books, what fruit comes about through that knowledge [gained by] learning, if they be not worshippers of the excellent feet of the One Who has true understanding?

evaṉeṉṉum viṉāppeyar eṉṉeṉṟāy īṇṭiṉmai kuṟittu niṉṟatu. kolleṉpa tacainilai. piṟavippiṇikku maruntākaliṉ ‘naṟṟāḷ’ eṉṟār ākama vaṟiviṟkuppayaṉ avaṉṟāḷait toḻutu piṟavi yaṟuttaleṉpatu itaṉāṟ kūṟappaṭṭatu.

[The interrogative base form?] "evaṉ," becoming the interrogative [pro]noun "eṉ," stands here pointing to [the sense of] nonexistence. The [term] "pray" is [an expletive that occupies] the space of a metrical part-foot (acai). [Tiruvaḷḷuvar] has said "good feet" because [they] are the remedy for the fetter of birth. Through this [Kuṟaḷ?], it has been stated that the fruit of the knowledge of scripture/tradition is the cutting-off of [re]birth [subsequent to] serving His feet.
(i - ḷ.) mēṟkūṟiya veḻuttiṉā ṉākiya coṟka ḷellāṅ kaṟṟataṉā ṉākiya payaṉ vēṟiyātu? viḷaṅkiṉa vaṟiviṉai yuṭaiyavaṉ tiruvaṭiyait toḻārāyiṉ, (e - ṟu).
The meaning ... : What other fruit is [gained] by studying all the words that are [formed] by the above-mentioned letters, if they do not serve the holy feet of Him Who has radiant knowledge?
colliṉāṉē poru ḷaṟiyappaṭumātalāṉ ataṉaik kaṟkavē meyyuṇarntu vīṭu peṟalākum. “kaṟpak kaḻimaṭa maḵkum” eṉṟāru muḷar.

Because it is only through the word that the meaning comes to be known, it is only after studying(?) that, after reflecting on the true meaning, liberation is obtained. And there are those who say that [even] great ignorance subsides after studying(?).
mīṇṭum vaṇakkam kūṟiyatu eṟṟukkeṉṟārkku, kaṟṟataṉāl payaṉ itu veṉpatūum, vēṟu vēṟu payaṉ illai yeṉpatūum kūṟiṟṟu.

As for those who ask, "why has [a verse expressing] obeisance again been uttered?", the [content expressed here and not in the first verse is that??] this is the fruit [gained] by learning, and that there is no other and different fruit.
